channel.title: Strange-Influenced Work on
channel.description: Recent content in Strange-Influenced Work on

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Blayne Haggart. In Information, Technology and Control in a Changing World: Understanding Power Structures in the 21st Century. Blayne Haggart, Kathryn Henne, Natasha Tusikov, editors. 25-52. Cham: Palgrave Macmillan, 2019. According to many observers, economic globalization and the liberalization of telecoms/internet policy have remade the world in the image of the United States. The dominant roles of Amazon, Apple, Facebook, and Google have also led to charges of US internet imperialism.

item.title: Susan Strange 1923-1998: A Great International Relations Theorist
item.description: Ronen Palan. Review of International Political Economy 6, no. 2 (1999): 121-132. Keywords: Theory; Other Text access (external link)

item.title: Strange fruit: Susan Strange's theory of structural power in the international political economy
item.description: Christopher May. Global Society 10, no. 2 (1996): 167-189. Keywords: Structural Power, Power; Knowledge Text access (external link)

item.title: 'Take six eggs': theory, finance, and the real economy in the work of Susan Strange
item.description: Robert W. Cox. In Approaches to World Order. Robert W. Cox, Timothy J. Sinclair, editors. 174-187. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1992. Keywords: Theory; Finance Text access (external link)
